Documenting 75 years of scientific innovation https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/november/75-years-of-scientific-innovation New British Library 'Voices of Science' website to record the lives of British scientists in full for the first time Dr Sally Horrocks (pictured)\ufffd\ufffdfrom the School of History has been involved in a major oral history project to gather the life stories of British scientists.

The collaborative work has culminated in the launch by the British Library of a new website, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdVoices of Science\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, that showcases the results of this project.

The website features interviews with over 100 leading UK scientists and engineers, telling the stories of some of the most remarkable scientific and engineering discoveries of the past century as well as the personal stories of each individual.

Over 1000 hours of unedited interviews, each lasting 10-15 hours, are being made available in full on the British Library\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Sounds website, while the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdVoices of Science\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd site offers curated access to audio and video highlights from the interviews, as well as photographs, biographies and other contextual information.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Physics Physics and Astronomy Chemistry Biology Medicine Magazine:Research Magazine:Student Magazine:Business Magazine:Staff 2013-11-29T12:18:46Z Blog Entry EU Horizon 2020 is coming; EU Funding and learning from colleagues\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd experiences https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2013/december/eu-horizon-2020-is-coming-eu-funding-and-learning-from-colleagues2019-experiences Frank and Katherine May Lecture Theatre, Henry Wellcome Building - 11 Dec 2013, 03:00PM - 05:00PM No publisher User Submitted College:MedBioPsych Biology Chemistry Event:Lecture Physics 2013-12-11T15:00:00Z UoL Event 'Rho GTPases: signalling in cell adhesion and migration' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2014/february/rho-gtpases-signalling-in-cell-adhesion-and-migration Frank and Katherine May Lecture Theatre, Henry Wellcome Building - 07 Feb 2014, 12:30PM - 01:30PM Lecture title - Rho GTPases: signalling in cell adhesion and migration.

]]> No publisher User Submitted Biology College:MedBioPsych Event:Lecture 2014-02-07T12:30:00Z UoL Event The company you keep influences what you learn https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/november/the-company-you-keep-influences-what-you-learn Research into desert locusts discovers how your environment shapes your thinking Desert locusts are notorious for their devastating swarms when food is scarce.

However, they do not always live in swarms \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd they switch between a lone living \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsolitary phase' and a swarming \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgregarious\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd phase. The two phases differ profoundly in looks, behaviour and in their life style.

Academics from the\ufffd\ufffdUniversity have teamed up with academics from\ufffd\ufffdSussex and Cambridge to show how the environment shapes learning and memory, through\ufffd\ufffdtraining locusts - in a manner that recalls\ufffd\ufffdthe conditioning of Pavlov's dogs -\ufffd\ufffdto associate different smells, either vanilla or lemon,\ufffd\ufffdwith reward or punishment.

The results show how brains do not solve problems \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdin a vacuum\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd but in interaction with the environment.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Biology Magazine:Staff 2013-11-21T17:00:22Z Blog Entry 'Texture & Foliage' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2014/march/texture-foliage Thursday 20 March at 7:30pm in Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 3 Annual General Meeting

Brian is a well-known nurseryman and plant enthusiast with a passion for collecting rare and unusual plants, mainly herbaceous perennials and grasses. In this illustrated talk, Brian shows how foliage is as important as flowers in the garden.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Biology College:MedBioPsych Event:Lecture Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2014-03-20T19:30:00Z UoL Event 'Unusual Vegetables From Seed' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2014/february/unusual-vegetables-from-seed Tuesday 18 February at 7:30pm in the Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 2 Founder of Original Touch World Garden Seeds, Samantha Ford's gardening talks embrace the modern culture of gardening as a way to eat healthily and interact in a more sympathetic way with our environment.

Samantha has an impressive knowledge of the origins of many of our more familiar vegetable varieties, as well as others which are more unusual. Her research has also uncovered many forgotten elements of the folklore surrounding what we eat, which will throw a whole new light on your humble vegetable garden or allotment.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Event:Lecture Biology College:MedBioPsych Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2014-02-18T19:30:00Z UoL Event 'The Royal Gardens, Windsor' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2014/january/the-royal-gardens-windsor Thursday 23 January at 7:30pm in the Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 3 Jeff trained at Windsor Castle, and has worked as lecturer and designer. He has a particular interest in historic gardens. He has been a judge for East Midlands in Bloom for 25 years, and is co-Vice-Chair of Britain in Bloom.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Event:Lecture Biology College:MedBioPsych Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2014-01-23T19:30:00Z UoL Event 'Garden Folklore' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2013/december/garden-folklore Thursday 5 December at 7:30pm in the Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 3 A second- generation gardener, Stuart trained at Stapeley Water Gardens, then at Kew. He has lectured at two horticultural colleges and is now a consultant and lecturer. A popular speaker, he is author of An Encyclopaedia of Plants in Myth, Magic, Legend and Lore, published by Robert Hale Ltd, 2011.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Event:Lecture Biology College:MedBioPsych Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2013-12-05T19:30:00Z UoL Event 'The Way We Gardened Then' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2013/november/the-way-we-gardened-then Thursday 14 November at 7:30pm in the Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 3 This talk builds on Doug\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds passion for collecting and reading old gardening magazines, brochures and books. How did we garden over 60 years ago and how much have things changed from the humble shed, to the flower show and of course the very latest products and devices to make gardening easy?

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Biology College:MedBioPsych Event:Lecture Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2013-11-14T19:30:00Z UoL Event New support to train the next generation of environmental researchers https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/november/new-support-to-train-the-next-generation-of-environmental-researchers Leicester to benefit from \ufffd\ufffd100 million national windfall for postgraduate training Doctoral studies at Leicester are to benefit from a share of \ufffd\ufffd100 million announced by Science and Universities minister David Willetts for new NERC investment in fifteen Doctoral Training Partnerships (DTPs), which specialise in training environmental science PhD students.

The DTPs will support 1200 PhD students across the fifteen partnerships. This means at least 240 new students will begin training every year for five years

The University will play a key part in the new programme and is one of seven partners of the Central England NERC Training Alliance (CENTA), led by the University of Birmingham. Leicester has expertise in a number of areas where the CENTA partnership has particular research strength, and the support from NERC will allow more students to take up opportunities of researching these environmental issues.

The funding will be used to support a broad range of subjects across environmental sciences and several of our departments are expected to be involved in the programme, including Biology, Chemistry, Genetics, Geography, Geology, Physics and Astronomy.

  • Press release
  • Find out more about PhD study at Leicester
]]> No publisher pt91 Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Geology Genetics Magazine:Staff Geography Biology Chemistry 2013-11-05T15:58:29Z Blog Entry Hog Watchers Wanted https://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/estates/environment/news/2013-news/hog-watchers-wanted Your help is required to locate Leicester's dwindling hedgehog population. Hedgehogs have been in decline in recent years with no real estimate of their populations. The dwindling numbers of hedgehogs is being caused by the destruction of their natural habitats as homeowners pave their gardens and tarmac their drives.

Leicester City Council is now asking for your help to find and locate the hedgehogs of Leicester to help get a better understanding of the local population. At the end of July and beginning of August the summer litter of hoglets will just be getting ready to leave the nest and become independent so there could be lots of hungry youngsters looking for food in your urban garden.
It\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds easy to do your part \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd just log any sightings of hedgehogs on the simple survey and email to hog-watch@leicester.gov.uk.
More information

]]> No publisher sll33 Sustainability Biology Environment 2013-07-30T11:35:00Z Blog Entry Insect study could help boost prosthetic limb development https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/insects-study-could-boost-robotic-limb-development University of Leicester study shows insects can move without muscles using \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdclever biomechanical tricks\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Neurobiologists from the University of Leicester have shown that insect limbs can move without muscles \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a finding that may provide engineers with new ways to improve the control of robotic and prosthetic limbs.

The study, published today in the journal Current Biology helps to explain how insects control their movements using a close interplay of neuronal control and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdclever biomechanical tricks\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

Research shows that the structure of some insect leg joints causes the legs to move even in the absence of muscles. So-called \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdpassive joint forces\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd serve to return the limb back towards a preferred resting position.

The passive movements differ in limbs that have different behavioural roles and different musculature, suggesting that the joint structures are specifically adapted to complement muscle forces. The researchers propose a motor control scheme for insect limb joints in which not all movements are driven by muscles.

Dr Tom Matheson, from the Department of Biology at the University of Leicester led the research and said he hoped the research on locusts and grasshoppers would \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdspur a new understanding of how limbs work and can be controlled, by not just insects, but by other animals, people, and even by robots\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

  • Press release
]]> No publisher er134 Magazine:Staff Neuroscience Magazine:Research Biology Magazine:Student Engineering 2013-07-18T16:08:38Z Blog Entry From Romans to \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRing Rain\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Festival of Postgraduate Research returns https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/june/from-romans-to-2018ring-rain2019-leicester2019s-festival-of-postgraduate-research-returns Cutting edge research on display at the University of Leicester on 27 June 2013 The Graduate School is hosting the ninth annual Festival of Postgraduate Research on Thursday 27 June 2013, where a range of the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds postgraduate researchers will communicate their cutting edge work to academics, employers, and the general public.

The Festival opens at 11am in the Charles Wilson Building on the main campus.

Fifty of the University's best research students have been chosen to present their work at this year's Festival with presentations covering everything from the use of Roman military bases as social spaces, the search for novel biomarkers of heart failure, examining Saturn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdraining rings\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, to the political representation of animals.

Admission is free and everyone is welcome to attend, so book your place online now.

To learn more about our Festival presenters, you can view the presenter profiles for follow the Graduate School's Facebook page.

  • Press release
]]> No publisher er134 Geography Chemistry Postgraduate Cardiovascular Holocaust Modern Languages Magazine:Business Engineering I-Science Infection, Immunity and Inflammation Economics Sociology Geology Medical and Social Care Education Mathematics Genetics Magazine:Research English Graduate School Victorian Cancer Studies and Molecular Medicine Magazine:Student INstitute of Lifelong Learning Criminology Computer Science Media and Communications Museum Studies History of Art and Film Archaeology Management Urban History Health Sciences Country House Cell Physiology and Pharmacology American Studies Education Biology Biochemistry Labour Mafrket Studies Magazine:Staff Psychology Stanley Burton Centre Physics and Astronomy History Law 2013-06-19T13:40:00Z Blog Entry Father's Day: Dads show plenty of (stickle)back-bone https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/june/father-s-day-dad-s-show-plenty-of-stickle-back-bone Male stickleback fish deserve extra praise this Father\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Day, in light of findings by University of Leicester researchers This Father\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Day, spare a thought for three-spined stickleback fish \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd who may have been having a tough time this year, according to Leicester biologists.

Dr Iain Barber (pictured), Head of the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Department of Biology, is leading a study of three-spined sticklebacks\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd nesting habits.

The fish, which live in the sea as well as in lakes and rivers, build their nests during the spring \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and unlike many other nesting animals, it is the fathers, rather than mothers, who are responsible for nest building and parental care until the fish are strong enough to swim away.

Unable to put their feet up like most Dads this Sunday, the severe rainfall experienced across Europe during the spring months, which is when the fish build their nests, is likely to have made this task much more difficult.

The males build nests from algae, sand and debris, which they glue together using a protein called \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdspiggin\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, formed in their kidneys. To ensure that the nests are strong enough to withstand the heavier currents, they must produce more of this glue, which uses up more energy.

Dr Barber and his team are observing the fish in their laboratory to see how their behaviour changes for different water flow rates, and are being careful to ensure the conditions are within the spectrum of what the fish would experience in their natural environments.

The good news is - the fish appear to be adapting very well.

Three-spined sticklebacks are regarded as something of an evolutionary \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsupermodel\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd due to their remarkable ability to adapt to environmental change.

You can catch Dr Iain Barber and the stickleback Dad's on BBC's The One Show here

  • Read the press release
]]> No publisher er134 Magazine:Staff Biology Magazine:Student Magazine:Research 2013-06-14T08:45:00Z Blog Entry Science for Sustainability in Kenya https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/may/science-for-sustainability-in-kenya Field course run by the Centre for Interdisciplinary Science leaves a lasting impact for rural communities in Kenya The \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdSustainable Livelihoods\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd field course, led by David Harper, a Professor in the Department of Biology, is run each year by the Centre for Interdisciplinary Science at the University of Leicester.

Students who take part in the field course travel to Lake Bogoria in Kenya and work with members of the local community on sustainability themed projects, such as\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdovergrazing\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdinvasive species\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsolar power\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

The students apply skills learnt during their degree in Leicester to solving real life problems.

For more information about this year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds field trip click here
